Dynamic Hamiltonian Monte Carlo¶

class pysip.mcmc.hmc.DynamicHMC(hamiltonian)[source]¶

Dynamic Hamiltonian Monte Carlo Sampler with Multinomial sampling

Parameters

hamiltonian (EuclideanHamiltonian) – Hamiltonian system with Euclidean-Gaussian kinetic energies

References: Betancourt, M., 2017. A conceptual introduction to Hamiltonian Monte Carlo. arXiv preprint arXiv:1701.02434.

_build_tree(depth, direction, state, stepsize, H0, sum_p, sum_w, stats)[source]¶

Recursively build the binary tree

Parameters

  • depth (int) – Depth of the desired subtree

  • direction (int) – direction in time to build subtree [-1 or 1]

  • state (NamedTuple) – State proposed from the subtree

  • stepsize (float) – Step-size of the leapfrog integrator

  • H0 (float) – Hamiltonian of the initial state

  • sum_p (float) – Summed momentum accross trajectory

  • sum_w (float) – Summed weight accross trajectory

  • stats (dict) – Trajectory statistics - accept_prob: Summed acceptance probability accross trajectory - leapfrog_steps: Summed number of leapfrog integrations - diverging: Flag for diverging transition

Return type

Tuple[bool, NamedTuple, NamedTuple, NamedTuple, float]

Returns

5-elements tuple with

stop: Flag indicating a divergent transition or a U-turn state_inner: State of the inner subtree state_outer: State of the outer subtree state_proposed: State of the proposed subtree sum_w: Summed weight accross trajectory

  • p (ndarray) – Momentum in phase space

_leapfrog_step(state, direction, stepsize)[source]¶

Explicit leapfrog integrator for separable Hamiltonian systems

Parameters

  • state (NamedTuple) – State of the Hamiltonian at the current point in phase space

  • direction (int) – Time direction for integration, e.g forward=1, backward=-1

  • stepsize (float) – Step-size of the leapfrog integrator

Return type

NamedTuple

Returns

State of the Hamiltonian a step further in the trajectory

Sample a chain

Parameters

  • q (ndarray) – Initial position variables

  • pbar (trange) – Progress bar

  • stepsize (float) – Initial step-size of the leapfrog integrator

  • step_adapter (DualAveraging) – Dual averaging algorithm for learning the step-size

  • cov_adapter (CovAdaptation) – Windowed Welford covariance estimator

Returns

Return type

chain

_transition(state, stepsize)[source]¶

Dynamic Hamiltonian Monte Carlo transition with multinomial sampling

Parameters

  • state (NamedTuple) – Hamiltonian state at the current point in phase space

  • stepsize (float) – Step-size of the leapfrog integrator

Returns

Next Hamiltonian state stats: Trajectory statistics

  • accept_prob: Average acceptance probability accross trajectory

  • leapfrog_steps: Number of leapfrog steps

  • diverging: Flag for diverging transition

  • energy: Hamiltonian at the next state

  • tree_depth: Depth of the binary tree

  • max_tree_depth: Flag for maximum integration steps

  • stepsize: Step-size of the leapfrog integrator

  • potential: Potential energy (negative log-posterior)

Return type

state_n

sample(q, n_draws=2000, n_chains=4, n_warmup=1000, options=None)[source]¶

Draw samples from the target distribution

Parameters

  • q (ndarray) – Initial position variables (e.g. initial parameters)

  • n_draws (int) – Number of samples

  • n_chains (int) – Number of Markov chains

  • n_warmup (int) – Number of iterations to use for adapting the step size and the mass matrix

  • options (Optional[dict]) –

    • stepsize (float, default=0.25 / n_par**0.25)

      Step-size of the leapfrog integrator

    • dense_mass_matrix (bool, default=False)

      Estimate the dense mass matrix during adaptation. By default, only the diagonal elements are estimated.

    • shrinkage (bool, default=True)

      Shrink towards unity the diagonal elements of the estimated mass matrix

    • max_tree_depth (int, default=10)

      Maximum tree depth

    • dH_max (float, default=1000)

      Maximum energy change allowed in a trajectory. Larger deviations are considered as diverging transitions.

    • accp_target (float, default=0.8):

      Target average acceptance probability. Valid values are between ]0, 1[

    • t0 (float, default=10.0):

      Adaptation iteration offset (primal-dual averaging algorithm parameter)

    • gamma (float, default=0.05):

      Adaptation regularization scale (primal-dual averaging algorithm parameter)

    • kappa (float, default=0.75):

      Adaptation relaxation exponent (primal-dual averaging algorithm parameter)

    • mu (float, default=log(10 * stepsize)):

      Asymptotic mean of the step-size (primal-dual averaging algorithm parameter)

    • n_cpu: (int, default=-1):

      Number of cpu to use. To use all available cpu, set the value to -1, otherwise valid values are between [1, +Inf[

    • init_buffer: (int, default=75)

      Width of initial fast adaptation interval

    • term_buffer: (int, default=100)

      Width of final fast adaptation interval

    • window: (int, default=25)

      Initial width of slow adaptation interval

Returns

Markov chain traces stats: Hamiltonian transition statistics df: Hamiltonian sampler diagnostic

Return type

chains

property diagnostic¶

Sampler diagnostic

Returns

Sampler diagnostic

Return type

df

Notes

EBFMI (Energy Bayesian Fraction of Missing Information) values below 0.3 indicates that momentum resampling will ineffciently explore the energy level sets.

Hamiltonian system¶

class pysip.mcmc.hamiltonian.EuclideanHamiltonian(potential, metric)[source]¶

Hamiltonian System

\begin{align*} H(q, p) &= -\log \pi(p \mid q) -\log \pi(q) \\ &= K(p, q) + V(q) \end{align*}

where \(H(q, p)\) is the Hamiltonian function with \(q\) and \(p\), the position and momentum variables in phase space. \(K(p, q)\) is the Kinetic energy and \(V(q)\) is the potential energy. The potential energy is completely determined by the target distribution while the kinetic energy is specified by the implementation.

Hamiltonian’s equations

\begin{align*} \frac{\mathrm{d}q}{\mathrm{d}t} &= \frac{\partial H}{\partial p} = \frac{\partial K}{\partial p} \\ \frac{\mathrm{d}p}{\mathrm{d}t} &= -\frac{\partial H}{\partial q} = -\frac{\partial K}{\partial q} - \frac{\partial V}{\partial q} \end{align*}

For Euclidean-Gaussian kinetic energy

\begin{align*} K(p) &= \frac{1}{2} p M^{-1} p + \log \lvert M \rvert + \text{const.} \\ &\propto \frac{1}{2} p M^{-1} p \end{align*}

with \(M\) the mass matrix, the Hamiltonian system is separable such that

\begin{align*} H(q, p) &= -\log \pi(p) -\log \pi(q) \\ &= K(p) + V(q) \end{align*}

which simplifies the Hamiltonian’s equations to

\begin{align*} \frac{\mathrm{d}q}{\mathrm{d}t} &= \frac{\partial H}{\partial p} = \frac{\partial K}{\partial p}\\ \frac{\mathrm{d}p}{\mathrm{d}t} &= -\frac{\partial H}{\partial q} = -\frac{\partial V}{\partial q} \end{align*}
Parameters

  • potential (Callable) – Function which evaluate the potential energy and the gradient at a given position

  • metric (EuclideanMetric) – Diagonal or Dense Euclidean metric

References

Betancourt, M., 2017. A conceptual introduction to Hamiltonian Monte Carlo. arXiv preprint arXiv:1701.02434.
